member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.EnableThemingInScope
member.summary: This class is intended to be used with the 'using' statement, to activate an activation context for turning on visual theming at the beginning of a scope, and have it automatically deactivated when the scope is exited.
member.remarks: With a little bit of tuning, this old traditional model, still works even in Windows 7. In our case we need it to apply theming to the native Print dialog of the view. It may be useless in the future.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.JavascriptDialogEventArgs.Handled
member.summary: Gets or sets if this event is handled by an application. The default is false.
member.remarks:
When set to false (default), a technology specific WebControl may display its predefined dialog (if any).
You can set this property to true and handle the event in the following ways:
Handling Procedure
Asynchronously
The WPF , automatically displays a in response to the event. Users can subclass to provide their own logic or look and feel if they want. If you style your , simply assign the command to the buttons of your dialog layer, specifying a CommandParameter of true or false to indicate OK or Cancel respectively.
Modally
In and any other technology specific WebControl, the event must be handled modally. Upon return, the and any other technology specific WebControl, internally responds to the calling web page.
WPF : If you are using a WPF , you can still handle the event modally, by calling
when you are done with processing the event.
You must always call if you handle the command modally.
member.exception: Attempting to set this property to false on a that has already been modally handled by calling .

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.DeferInput
member.summary: Enters a defer cycle that you can use to temporarily block all input to the view.
member.returns: A disposable that can be used with a using statement to create a defer cycle.
member.remarks: This method updates the status of input processing and adds the previous status to the stack.

example.code: ' Block all input. Using webView.DeferInput() ' Perform operations with all input blocked. End Using ' Restores input processing to its previous status.

member.exception: The member is called on an invalid view.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.DeferInput(Awesomium.Core.ViewInput)
member.summary: Enters a defer cycle that you can use to temporarily block specified input to the view.
member.param: A combination of input types specified in , indicating the input(s) to be blocked.
member.remarks: This method updates the status of input processing and adds the previous status to the stack.
member.returns: A disposable that can be used with a using statement to create a defer cycle.

example.code:
' Block mouse and touch input. Using webView.DeferInput( ViewInput.Mouse Or ViewInput.Touch )
' Perform operations with mouse and touch input blocked.
Using webView.DeferInput( ViewInput.Keyboard )
' Perform operations with mouse, touch and keyboard input blocked.
End Using ' Restores input processing to its previous status, blocking only ' mouse and touch input.
End Using ' Restores regular input processing.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.IsLive
member.summary: Gets if this view is alive.
member.remarks:
For a technology specific WebControl, this indicates the status of the underlying web-view the WebControl wraps.
Several technology specific WebControls, used to reflect the status of the underlying web-view, using their Enabled property (IsEnabled in WPF, Sensitive in Gtk# etc.). This behavior has now changed in favor of a common property (), common to all web-views.
The Enabled property of each WebControl, now only controls the rendering status of the underlying web-view of each WebControl.
For more details, refer to the documentation of each technology specific WebControl.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.SelfUpdate
member.summary: Gets or sets if this view should use an independent rendering timer.
member.remarks:
Setting this property to true will fail if is false. It is suggested that you check the value of before attempting to activate .
When auto-update is enabled (see ), updating and refreshing WebControls, is controlled by the using an internal timer, common for all views. The same timer is used to update the (see ) and fire events. While this is a light and effective technique, it is not ideal when you require high performance quality, such as when video content is displayed in views. In these scenarios, setting to true will tell the view to use an independent timer for rendering only, that will significantly improve the rendering quality, to the expense of CPU resources.
You should always combine the use of with the use of , or with the Enabled property of technology specific WebControls (IsEnabled in WPF, Sensitive in Gtk# etc.). When more than one views are using and they all display content that updates too fast (such as videos), controls that are currently not visible to the user (such as controls that are currently covered by other UI or used in a tab of a tab-control that is currently not visible), should have rendering paused by being disabled, to avoid draining out your CPU resources.
The default setting for all views is false, except WPF WebControl where the default setting is true. This is because in WPF only, we get more detailed notifications of when a control is loaded for presentation and thus we can update internally.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.IsRendering
member.summary: Gets or sets if internal asynchronous rendering is currently active.
member.remarks: All rendering is actually done asynchronously in a separate process and so the page is usually continuously rendering internally. Set this to false to temporarily pause rendering.
member.exception: The member is accessed on an invalid view.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.IWebView.NavigationInfo
member.summary: Gets or sets the navigation info level.
member.returns: A value indicating the level of navigation progress info reflected to the .
member.remarks:
Navigation progress information is reflected to the property:
Level Title Value
"None" Title only reflects the page's title, if any.
"Normal" Title reflects the page's title as well as "Error" and "Crashed" status.
"Verbose"
Title reflects progress status such as "Navigating..." and "Loading...", until the page's title is acquired. Also reflects "Error" and "Crashed" status.
Progress information can be localized by adding more localization resources to the assembly.

member.name: T:Awesomium.Core.WebCore
member.summary: The WebCore is the "core" of Awesomium; it manages the lifetime of all views (see and ) and maintains useful services like resource caching and network connections.
member.remarks:
Generally, you should initialize the WebCore () providing your custom configuration, before creating any views and shut it down () at the end of your program.
If you do not initialize , the core will automatically start, using default configuration, when you create the first view by either calling or by instantiating a .
Do not call any of the members of this class (other than or ) before starting the core.

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.Shutdown
member.summary: Destroys the and any lingering instances.
member.remarks: Make sure that this is not called while the hosting UI of any views created by this , is still live and visible. This method will destroy all views created by this . Any attempt to access them or any member of this class (other than and ) after calling this method, may throw a .

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebCore.Update
member.summary: Updates the and allows it to conduct various operations such as updating the render buffer of each view, destroying any views that are queued for destruction, and invoking any queued events (including .
member.remarks:
If you are using Awesomium from a UI thread (regular use), you never need to call this method. Internal auto-update takes care of this and you only need to watch for the event. If you are using Awesomium from a non graphical environment (Console application, Service or non-UI thread), auto-update is not available and you must manually call this method from either your application's message loop or by creating a timer. In this case, you must make sure that any calls to any of the classes of this assembly, are made from the same thread.
You can check to know if auto-update is already enabled.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.EnablePlugins
member.summary: Indicates whether or not to enable embedded plugins (e.g., Flash). The default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.EnableJavascript
member.summary: Indicates whether or not Javascript is enabled. The default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.EnableDatabases
member.summary: Indicates whether or not local HTML5 databases are enabled. (Will create a databases folder in the user data path if this is enabled). The default is false.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.UserDataPath
member.summary: Indicates the path to the directory that will be used to store cache, cookies, and other data. If an empty string is specified, this path defaults to CSIDL_APPDATA\Awesomium\Default.
member.remarks:
Relative paths are resolved against . That is, the path where the native Awesomium library is located.
If you set to true, please make sure that your hosting application is a single instance application, unless you are sure that you provide a unique for each of your application's instances. No more than one process/, can access the same cache at any given time.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.IsCacheUsed
member.summary: Gets if the currently set or the default cache if none is defined, is currently used by another application.

remarks.note: If you set to true, please make sure that your hosting application is a single instance application, unless you are sure that you provide a unique for each of your application's instances. No more than one process/, can access the same cache at any given time.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.PluginPath
member.summary: Indicates an absolute path that will be included in the search for plugins. This is useful if you wish to bundle certain plugins with your application.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.LogPath
member.summary: Indicates the path to store the awesomium.log. If none is specified, the log will be stored in CSIDL_APPDATA\Awesomium\.
member.remarks: Relative paths are resolved against . That is, the path where the native Awesomium library is located.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.LogLevel
member.summary: Indicates the logging level to use, this can be either , , or . The default is .

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.ForceSingleProcess
member.summary: Indicates whether or not all WebViews should be forced to render inside the main process (we typically launch a separate child-process to render each WebView and plugin safely).
member.remarks: This mode currently only works on Windows and automatically disables plugins and local databases. The default is false.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.ChildProcessPath
member.summary: Indicates the path to the child-process that we will use to render WebViews and plugins (this will be AwesomiumProcess if you leave this empty). You can specify your own executable to handle the rendering but you will need to make sure that it calls .
member.remarks:
Currently, the use of a managed child process on Windows, is supported on Windows versions newer than and including Windows Vista.
Your applications must always distribute the default AwesomiumProcess alongside the Awesomium library.
On Windows systems such as Windows XP, setting this property to a managed child process, is ignored and the default rendering process (AwesomiumProcess) is used instead.
You can still use C/C++ custom child processes in all Windows versions supported by Awesomium.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.SystemSupportsManagedChildProcess
member.summary: Gets if the use of a managed custom child process (including ), is supported in the current operating system.
member.remarks:
Currently, the use of a managed child process on Windows, is supported on Windows versions newer than and including Windows Vista.
Your applications must always distribute the default AwesomiumProcess alongside the Awesomium library.
On Windows systems such as Windows XP, setting to a managed child process, is ignored and the default rendering process (AwesomiumProcess) is used instead.
You can still use C/C++ custom child processes in all Windows versions supported by Awesomium.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.LocalePath
member.summary: Indicates the path to the directory containing the en-US.dll file. Default is: ./ which indicates that the file lives alongside Awesomium.dll.
member.remarks: The specified path can be absolute, or relative to the location of Awesomium.dll.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.EnableAutoDetectEncoding
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the page encoding should be automatically detected. Default is true.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.AcceptLanguageOverride
member.summary: Set this to override the accept-language header for all WebViews. For example: "en-US" for English and "fr-FR" for French.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.DefaultCharsetOverride
member.summary: Set this to override the default charset for all WebViews.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.UserAgentOverride
member.summary: Indicates the user agent string that will be used to override the default. Leave this empty to use the default user agent.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.ProxyServer
member.summary: Indicates the proxy settings for all network requests. Specify "none" to disable all proxy use, specify "auto" to attempt to detect the proxy using system settings (e.g., via the Internet Properties dialog on Windows or the Network panel of System Preferences on Mac OSX). Specify anything else to set manual proxy settings.
member.example:
Possible values can be:
Value Description
"none" No proxy. (Default).
"auto" Detect system proxy settings.
"http=myproxy:80;ftp=myproxy2"
Use HTTP proxy "myproxy:80" for http:// URLs, and HTTP proxy "myproxy2:80" for ftp:// URLs.
"myproxy:80" Use HTTP proxy "foopy:80" for all URLs.
"socks4://myproxy" Use SOCKS v4 proxy "foopy:1080" for all URLs.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.ProxyConfigScript
member.summary: Indicates the URL to the PAC (Proxy Auto-Config) Script to use. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proxy_auto-config for more info.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.AuthServerWhitelist
member.summary: Gets or sets the list of servers that Integrated Authentication is allowed to silently provide user credentials for, when challenged.
member.remarks:
Integrated Authentication can authenticate the user to an Intranet server or proxy without prompting the user for a username or password. It does this by using cached credentials which are established when the user initially logs in to the machine that Awesomium is running on. Integrated Authentication is supported for Negotiate and NTLM challenges only.
In Windows only, if you do not set this property, the permitted list consists of those servers in the Local Machine or Local Intranet security zone (for example, when the host in the URL includes a "." character it is outside the Local Intranet security zone), which is the behavior present in IE.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.SaveCacheAndCookies
member.summary: Indicates whether or not cache and cookies should be saved to disk.

remarks.note: When you set this property to true, please make sure that your hosting application is a single instance application, unless you are sure that you provide a unique for each of your application's instances. No more than one process/, can access the same cache at any given time.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.MaxCacheSize
member.summary: Indicates the maximum disk space to be used by the disk cache, in bytes. Specify 0 to use no limit.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.DisableSameOriginPolicy
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the "same-origin" policy should be disabled. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Same_origin_policy.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebCoreConfig.CustomCSS
member.summary: Indicates a string of custom CSS to be included as the global default style for all pages. This is especially useful for customizing scrollbars and other look-and-feel elements.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebKeyboardEvent.VirtualKeyCode
member.summary: The virtual key-code associated with this keyboard event. This is either directly from the event (ie, WPARAM on Windows) or via a mapping function.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebKeyboardEvent.NativeKeyCode
member.summary: The actual key-code generated by the platform. The DOM specification primarily uses Windows-equivalent codes (hence virtualKeyCode above) but it helps to additionally specify the platform-specific key-code as well.

member.summary: The actual text generated by this keyboard event. This is usually only a single character but we're generous and cap it at a max of 4 characters.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebKeyboardEvent.UnmodifiedText
member.summary: The text generated by this keyboard event before all modifiers except shift are applied. This is used internally for working out shortcut keys. This is usually only a single character but we're generous and cap it at a max of 4 characters.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.WebKeyboardEvent.IsSystemKey
member.summary: Whether or not the pressed key is a "system key". This is a Windows-only concept and should be "false" for all non-Windows platforms. For more information, see the following link: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms646286.aspx

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebView.InjectKeyboardEventWin(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Injects a keyboard event by translating the respective Windows Messages.
member.param: The Windows keyboard message (usually WM_KEYDOWN, WM_KEYUP and WM_CHAR).
The first parameter of the message as intercepted by the window procedure.
The second parameter of the message as intercepted by the window procedure.
member.exception: The member is called on an invalid instance (see ).
member.remarks:
This is usually easier to use than . All you have to do is hook into the window procedure of this view's host, intercept WM_KEYDOWN, WM_KEYUP and WM_CHAR and inject them to the view by using this method.
Beware that in WPF, only the parent Window has a window procedure. Make sure that you only inject messages when the actual host (if it's a child element) has the focus, and that you do not hook into the same procedure multiple times.
member.exception: The member is called on an invalid instance (see ).

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebView.DeferInput
member.summary: Enters a defer cycle that you can use to temporarily block all input to the view.
member.returns: A disposable that can be used with a using statement to create a defer cycle.
member.remarks: This method updates the status of input processing and adds the previous status to the stack.

example.code: ' Block all input. Using webView.DeferInput() ' Perform operations with all input blocked. End Using ' Restores input processing to its previous status.

member.exception: The member is called on an invalid instance (see ).

member.name: M:Awesomium.Core.WebView.DeferInput(Awesomium.Core.ViewInput)
member.summary: Enters a defer cycle that you can use to temporarily block specified input to the view.
member.param: A combination of input types specified in , indicating the input(s) to be blocked.
member.remarks: This method updates the status of input processing and adds the previous status to the stack.
member.returns: A disposable that can be used with a using statement to create a defer cycle.

example.code:
' Block mouse and touch input. Using webView.DeferInput( ViewInput.Mouse Or ViewInput.Touch )
' Perform operations with mouse and touch input blocked.
Using webView.DeferInput( ViewInput.Keyboard )
' Perform operations with mouse, touch and keyboard input blocked.
End Using ' Restores input processing to its previous status, blocking only ' mouse and touch input.
End Using ' Restores regular input processing.

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.IsLive
member.summary: Gets if this is alive.
member.returns:
A value indicating if this , is alive. False indicates that the :
Crashed (see ).
Prematurely destroyed (see ).
Not properly instantiated. This means that something went wrong during instantiation of either the (if this is the first created) or of the itself.
member.remarks:
Developers should always check this property before calling members implemented by this . Trying to access the when it is not alive, can throw an .
There is no way to revive an invalid view. When you are done with reporting any errors to the user, dispose it and release any references to it to avoid memory leaks.

example.code:
Private Sub ToolStripButton2_Click( sender As Object, e As EventArgs ) Handles ToolStripButton2.Click If Not m_WebView.IsLive Then Return
m_WebView.GoForward() End Sub

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.SelfUpdate
member.summary: Gets or sets if this view should use an independent rendering timer.
member.remarks:
Setting this property to true will fail if is false. It is suggested that you check the value of before attempting to activate .
When auto-update is enabled (see ), updating and refreshing views, is controlled by the using an internal timer, common for all views. The same timer is used to update the (see ) and fire events. While this is a light and effective technique, it is not ideal when you require high performance quality, such as when video content is displayed in views. In these scenarios, setting to true will tell the view to use an independent timer for rendering only, that will significantly improve the rendering quality, to the expense of CPU resources.
You should always combine the use of with the use of . When more than one views are using and they all display content that updates too fast (such as videos), controls that are currently not visible to the user (such as controls that are currently covered by other UI or used in a tab of a tab-control that is currently not visible), should have rendering paused (see ), to avoid draining out your CPU resources.
The default setting for is false.
member.exception: The member is accessed on an invalid instance (see ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.IsRendering
member.summary: Gets or sets if internal asynchronous rendering is currently active.
member.remarks: All rendering is actually done asynchronously in a separate process and so the page is usually continuously rendering internally. Set this to false to temporarily pause rendering.
member.exception: The member is accessed on an invalid instance (see ).

member.name: P:Awesomium.Core.WebView.NavigationInfo
member.summary: Gets or sets the navigation info level.
member.returns: A value indicating the level of navigation progress info reflected to the . The default is .
member.remarks:
Navigation progress information is reflected to the control's :
Level Title Value
"None" Title only reflects the page's title, if any.
"Normal"
Title reflects the page's title as well as "Error" and "Crashed" status. (Default)
"Verbose"
Title reflects progress status such as "Navigating..." and "Loading...", until the page's title is acquired. Also reflects "Error" and "Crashed" status.
Progress information can be localized by adding more localization resources to the assembly.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.SynchronousWindowPosition
member.summary: If the calling thread and the thread that owns the window are attached to different input queues, the system posts the request to the thread that owns the window. This prevents the calling thread from blocking its execution while other threads process the request.
member.remarks: SWP_ASYNCWINDOWPOS

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.DeferErase
member.summary: Prevents generation of the WM_SYNCPAINT message.
member.remarks: SWP_DEFERERASE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.DrawFrame
member.summary: Draws a frame (defined in the window's class description) around the window.
member.remarks: SWP_DRAWFRAME

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.FrameChanged
member.summary: Applies new frame styles set using the SetWindowLong function. Sends a WM_NCCALCSIZE message to the window, even if the window's size is not being changed. If this flag is not specified, WM_NCCALCSIZE is sent only when the window's size is being changed.
member.remarks: SWP_FRAMECHANGED

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.HideWindow
member.summary: Hides the window.
member.remarks: SWP_HIDEWINDOW

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotActivate
member.summary: Does not activate the window. If this flag is not set, the window is activated and moved to the top of either the topmost or non-topmost group (depending on the setting of the hWndInsertAfter parameter).
member.remarks: SWP_NOACTIVATE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotCopyBits
member.summary: Discards the entire contents of the client area. If this flag is not specified, the valid contents of the client area are saved and copied back into the client area after the window is sized or repositioned.
member.remarks: SWP_NOCOPYBITS

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.IgnoreMove
member.summary: Retains the current position (ignores X and Y parameters).
member.remarks: SWP_NOMOVE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotChangeOwnerZOrder
member.summary: Does not change the owner window's position in the Z order.
member.remarks: SWP_NOOWNERZORDER

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotRedraw
member.summary: Does not redraw changes. If this flag is set, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of the window being moved. When this flag is set, the application must explicitly invalidate or redraw any parts of the window and parent window that need redrawing.
member.remarks: SWP_NOREDRAW

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotReposition
member.summary: Same as the SWP_NOOWNERZORDER flag.
member.remarks: SWP_NOREPOSITION

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.DoNotSendChangingEvent
member.summary: Prevents the window from receiving the WM_WINDOWPOSCHANGING message.
member.remarks: SWP_NOSENDCHANGING

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.IgnoreResize
member.summary: Retains the current size (ignores the cx and cy parameters).
member.remarks: SWP_NOSIZE

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.IgnoreZOrder
member.summary: Retains the current Z order (ignores the hWndInsertAfter parameter).
member.remarks: SWP_NOZORDER

member.name: F:Awesomium.Windows.NativeMethods.SetWindowPosFlags.ShowWindow
member.summary: Displays the window.
member.remarks: SWP_SHOWWINDOW

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.RenderOperations.PaintAtResize
member.summary: Create a new bitmap wrapping the native pixel buffer in memory, when none is created yet, or when the pixel buffer has been resized. When its size is not changed, copy the native pixel buffer to the bitmap.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.RenderOperations.Paint
member.summary: Always create a new bitmap, wrapping the native pixel buffer in memory.

member.name: F:Awesomium.Core.RenderOperations.Copy
member.summary: Create a new bitmap only when none is created yet, or when the pixel buffer has been resized. Then copy the native pixel buffer to the new bitmap.
